Chapter 7, Part 2: Right Efforts. As for in order to prevent unwholesome states that have not yet arisen from arising, one generates desire, strives, arouses energy, exerts the mind, and upholds the mind, what are unwholesome states that have not yet arisen?
It refers to the five hindrances in the future.
What is right effort in order to prevent unwholesome states that have not yet arisen from arising?

It means that a bhiká¹£u, in order to permanently prevent the arising of the greed and sensual desire hindrance that has not yet arisen, contemplates in accordance with principle that this greed and sensual desire hindrance has many faults, namely, it is an unwholesome state, and is believed and upheld by the lowly.

It is despised by the Buddha, disciples, the virtuous and noble, and can lead to harm for oneself, harm for others, and harm for both; it can destroy wisdom, obstruct that kind of person, and hinder the attainment of cessation.
Upholding those dharmas, one does not give rise to penetrating insight, does not attract enlightenment, and does not realize nirvana.

Contemplating in this way, one gives rise to diligent effort, vigorous strength, fierce ferocity, blazing intensity, and unbridled exertion, and one's mind is not at rest. This path is called the right exertion that causes the arising of the previously non-arisen greed-and-lust obscuration.
Having given rise to this path, due to cultivating it and cultivating it extensively, one causes the previously non-arisen greed-and-lust obscuration to be forever unarisen.

Arising of desire means that in order to cause the previously non-arisen greed-and-lust obscuration to be forever unarisen, one gives rise to, gives rise to equally, gives rise to birth, gives rise to birth equally, accumulates, and appears. It is the desire, enjoyment, delight, seeking, and longing.
Due to giving rise to these desires, one causes the previously non-arisen greed-and-lust obscuration to be forever unarisen.

One who arouses zeal means that in order to prevent the arising of the previously non-arisen cover of sensual desire, one arouses zeal, and so on up to one exerts oneself and does not relax. Because of this, one prevents the previously non-arisen cover of sensual desire from arising.

One who exerts the mind means that in order to prevent the arising of the previously non-arisen cover of sensual desire, one diligently cultivates a mind accompanied by joy, a mind accompanied by delight, a mind accompanied by exertion, a mind not inferior, a mind not obscured, a mind accompanied by equanimity, and a mind accompanied by concentration.
Because one cultivates such a mind, one prevents the previously non-arisen cover of sensual desire from arising.
One who upholds the mind means that in order to prevent the arising of the previously non-arisen cover of sensual desire, one upholds the mind and cultivates the eightfold noble path.
Because one upholds the mind and cultivates this path, one prevents the previously non-arisen cover of sensual desire from arising.

Moreover, there is a bhiká¹£u who, in order to cause the arising of the previously non-arisen sensual desire cover to be permanently unarisen, contemplates the merit of going forth in accordance with principle. In this way, going forth is the true good dharma, it is the superior one who believes and practices it, and so on in detail, up to being able to realize nirvÄá¹‡a.

Having given rise to this path, due to cultivating it and frequently practicing it, one causes the previously non-arisen sensual desire cover to be permanently unarisen.
Generating desire and so on, up to encouraging the mind and upholding the mind, are all as explained above.

It refers to the four future meditations, three formless concentrations, and other wholesome dharmas that arise from renouncing the world and living in seclusion.

Having given rise to this path, through cultivation and much practice, one causes the first meditation that has not yet arisen to arise.

As for giving rise to desire, in order to give rise to the first meditation that has not yet arisen, one gives rise to desire, equalizes desire, gives rise to desire and equalizes desire, accumulates desire, and causes desire to appear. One desires, delights, seeks, aspires, and hopes.

Having given rise to this path, through cultivating it and frequently practicing it, they give rise to the wholesome states that arise from renunciation and seclusion of various kinds that have not yet arisen.

Having given rise to this path, through cultivating and repeatedly practicing it, he causes the first meditation that has already arisen to be firmly maintained, up to realizing it through knowledge.

Because of the arising of these desires, one makes the already arisen first meditation firm, up to the realization of knowledge.

Exertion in vigor means that in order to make the already arisen first meditation firm, up to the realization of knowledge, one exerts vigor, explains in detail up to striving with a concentrated mind.
Because of this, one makes the already arisen first meditation firm, up to the realization of knowledge.

Because of giving rise to this desire, one causes the wholesome states arisen from going forth and seclusion of a certain kind to be firmly established, up to realizing it through knowledge.

One who generates effort refers to one who generates effort in order to firmly maintain, up to realizing knowledge, the wholesome states that have arisen, such as renunciation and seclusion. In detail, it means to not cease exerting oneself.

Why are these four called right exertions?
Because these four are non-erroneous, they are called right;
because they have the power to eliminate evil and cultivate good, they are called exertions.
Moreover, these four are equal, not unequal, real, true, in accordance with proper principles, and non-erroneous, so they are called right;
because they are increased, superior, supreme, and excellent, and have great efficacy, they are called exertions.

Moreover, the four right exertions are nominally established names, concepts, and verbal expressions called right exertions, because the buddhas and disciples, more numerous than the sands of the Ganges River, all establish this name.

Furthermore, the four right efforts are: for the sake of cutting off evil and unwholesome dharmas that have already arisen, one gives rise to various desires, exerts diligent effort, encourages the mind, and upholds the mind.ğŸ”½For the sake of preventing unarisen evil and unwholesome dharmas from arising, one gives rise to various desires, exerts diligent effort, encourages the mind, and upholds the mind.

For the sake of causing arisen wholesome dharmas to abide firmly, not to be forgotten, to be cultivated and perfected, to be doubled, increased, expanded, and to realize wisdom, one gives rise to various desires, exerts diligent effort, encourages the mind, and upholds the mind.
Being endowed with such abilities, they are called right efforts;
they are also called right abandonments, because they cut off laziness.
